revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Expert needed|Sociology|date=September 2012}} {{too few opinions|date=May 2012}} {{Primary sources|article|date=September 2012}} }} Established in 2008 by Nathan Taback, Christina Willie and Robin Coupland, '''Insecurity Insight''' is a [[Geneva]]-based non-profit organisation that has developed the ”Taback-Coupland model of armed violence”, a model that is used to generate data on the impact of armed [[violence]] and insecurity on people's lives and wellbeing with a view to generating preventive policies.
{{Infobox organization | name = Insecurity Insight | logo = Insecurity Insight.png | logo_size = 200px | type = Non-profit | founded_date = 2008 | founder = Nathan Taback, Christina Willie and Robin Coupland | location = Geneva, Switzerland | focus = Design and implementation of research on human security | homepage = [http://www.insecurityinsight.org insecurityinsight.org] }}
==History== While working in conflict zones as a [[general surgeon]] treating war wounds (1987-1995), Coupland developed a [[theory]] about armed violence and its effects. The theory states that the effects of use of [[weapons]] on [[health]] have certain identifiable determinants:<ref name=pmid15690624>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/1362369042000315032 |title=Towards Collation and Modelling of the Global Cost of Armed Violence on Civilians |year=2005 |last1=Taback |first1=Nathan |last2=Coupland |first2=Robin |journal=Medicine, Conflict and Survival |volume=21 |pmid=15690624 |pages=19–27 |issue=1}}{{psc|date=September 2012}}</ref>
*the victim's vulnerability; *the [[Lists of weapons|type of weapon]] or weapons used; *the potential number of weapons in use; *the psychological aspect of how the violence is perpetrated.
While teaching a course at the [[Harvard School of Public Health]] (2003), Coupland began collaborating with Taback, a statistician with an interest in [[global health]]. Their collaboration involved refining Coupland's original theory and developing the means to make quantifiable the various determinants for a given outcome of armed violence. The result has come to be known as the Taback-Coupland model of armed violence.<ref name="blogspot2007">{{cite web|last=Insight |first=Disarmament |url=http://disarmamentinsight.blogspot.com/2007/09/analyzing-armed-violence-taback.html |title=Disarmament Insight: Analyzing armed violence: the Taback - Coupland model |publisher=Disarmamentinsight.blogspot.com |date=2007-09-05 |accessdate=2012-05-27}}{{MEDRS|date=September 2012}}</ref>
Coupland and Taback later met Wille while she was working for the [[Small Arms Survey]] (2006), and applied the model to map the nature and extent of armed violence on a geographical basis. Willie worked on refining the model further and the structure of the corresponding [[databases]] to allow application of the model to analyze different kinds of violent events. Later Taback, Willie and Coupland founded Insecurity Insight (2008).
==Activities== The core activity of Insecurity Insight is to promote, use and make available to others the Taback-Coupland model. Because the model can be applied to any act of violence using any weapons resulting in any effect, the model has been applied to subjects such as [[explosion|explosive force]] in populated areas,<ref name="slideshare1">Action on Armed Violence (2009). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/02-13093711 Explosive Violence: The Problem of Explosive Weapons].”</ref> attacks on [[journalists]]<ref>Taback, Nathan and Robin Coupland (2006). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/09-13093705 Security of Journalists: Making the Case for Modelling Armed Violence as a Means to Promote Human Security].” Thinking Outside the Box in Multilateral Disarmament and Arms Control Negotiations by John Borrie and Vanessa Martin Randin (eds), 2006, United Nations publication, Sales No.GV.E.06.0.16; pp. 191–206.{{psc|date=September 2012}}</ref> and [[sexual violence]] in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jama.300.6.653 |title=Sexual Violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo |year=2008 |last1=Taback |first1=N. |last2=Painter |first2=R. |last3=King |first3=B. |journal=JAMA |volume=300 |issue=6 |pmid=18698063 |pages=653–4}}{{psc|date=September 2012}}</ref> and in [[Zimbabwe]]<ref>{{cite book | title=Electing to Rape: Sexual Terror in Mugabe's Zimbabwe | publisher=[[AIDS-Free World]] | year=December 2009 | pages=52 | url=http://www.aidsfreeworld.org/Publications-Multimedia/Reports/Electing-to-Rape.aspx}}</ref> and attacks on [[health care workers]] and [[Health care facilities|facilities]].<ref name="slideshare2">Coupland Robin, Christina Wille, Nathan Taback and Simon Regard, ICRC (2011). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/03-13093712 Sixteen Country Study: Health Care in Danger].”</ref>
A major ongoing project is the building of the “Security in Numbers Database.” This is a collaborative effort initiated by Insecurity Insight involving a number of major [[International nongovernmental organization|international humanitarian NGOs]]. By taking part in this project, these organisations share their security incidents with Insecurity Insight on a confidential basis; this permits analysis of these incidents by the model and therefore comparison of any single agency’s security issues with what is known globally about aid worker security. This has already generated findings.<ref>Wille, Christina and Larissa Fast (2011). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/06-13093715 Security Facts for Humanitarian Agencies: Aid, Gender and Security: The Gendered Nature of Security Events Affecting Aid Workers and Aid Delivery].”</ref><ref>Wille, Christina and Larissa Fast (2010) ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/05-13093714 Is Terrorism an Issue for Humanitarian Agencies?]” Perspectives 3 by the Security Management Initiative.</ref><ref>Wille Christina and Larissa Fast (2010). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/07-13093717 Security Facts for Humanitarian Agencies: How do security events affecting humanitarian agencies differ between rural and urban environments?]”</ref>
==Taback-Coupland model of armed violence== [[File:Taback Coupland.png|thumb|right|400px|The "Taback-Coupland model of armed violence."]]
Based on a standard [[public health]] model, the Taback-Coupland model takes as a starting point that use of weapons has a health impact and that this health impact is amenable to a preventive approach as any other public health issue. By generating data about threats to and vulnerabilities of people’s lives and well-being through violence and weapons, appropriate preventive policies can be proposed.<ref name="blogspot2007"/>
The model is constructed around four “[[risk factors]]” or determinants for any given effects of armed violence. The four determinants are the nature of the weapon, the number of weapons used (or potentially used), the way the weapon is used (the psychological aspect of the violence), and the victims’ vulnerability. An example is the lethality of attacks with [[firearms]]. This will be determined by:
*the kind of firearms (death is more likely if a larger [[caliber|calibre]] weapon is used, because the [[wound]] will be bigger); *how many firearms are being shot against the victim(s); *whether the user is standing close to (e.g. 5 metres) or further away (e.g. 200 metres) from the victim(s); *whether the victim(s) of the attack are cornered, tied up, can run away or take cover.
This example also shows the important interaction at a psychological level between how the weapon is used, the other determinants and perceptions of the potential outcome. (Whether the trigger is pulled to cause a fatal injury is influenced, for example, by whether the user of the firearm believes he or she can hit the victim(s) with it, whether there are others similarly armed, how easy it is to hit the victim(s) in that context, and whether the victim(s) have already been hit.)
===How to use the model=== The method uses written reports of real incidents of armed violence as the source for the necessary values. Information from a report on an individual incident is entered into a spreadsheet specially designed to capture and process information about the people committing violence and about the victim(s) or potential victim(s). In this way, qualitative sources of data about violence i.e., reports, can be fed into a specially prepared relational database; this uses [[binaries]] and surrogates to give a numeric value to determinants such as intent and vulnerability. (For example, for vulnerability: Were the people herded into a confined space before being shot? Yes / No) A “report” can be a very short text as indicated by the following sentence: “Two masked men entered Hospital X last night and shot dead a sleeping patient.” In terms of entry into the database, this can be read as: Two masked men [number of people armed] entered Hospital X [where] last night [when] and shot [weapon (firearms)] dead [outcome] a [outcome] sleeping patient [vulnerability]. ("Shot dead" is also a comment on intent.)
When the database has been fed with a sufficient number of reports of real events about a certain issue, this permits an “evidence-based” dialogue about the perpetrators and their intents and about the victims and their vulnerabilities. Taback and Coupland tested the model using [[global news]] reports about violence in general<ref name=pmid15690624/> and about attacks on journalists.<ref>Taback, Nathan and Robin Coupland (2006). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/09-13093705 Security of Journalists: Making the Case for Modelling Armed Violence as a Means to Promote Human Security].”{{psc|date=September 2012}}</ref> They went further and termed such an approach “the science of human security.”<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/13623690601084518 |title=The science of human security |year=2007 |last1=Taback |first1=Nathan |last2=Coupland |first2=Robin |journal=Medicine, Conflict and Survival |volume=23 |pmid=17370855 |pages=3–9 |issue=1}}{{psc|date=September 2012}}</ref>
All important limitations of the data gathering method based on the model relate to the completeness and accuracy of the qualitative reports which are fed into the model. However, as Taback and Coupland have pointed out, reports, especially media reports may be the only information available about a given context or form of violence in multiple contexts. It is nevertheless possible to generate policy-relevant quantitative data from such sources. Further, they point out that while there are international surveillance systems for monitoring [[outbreak|infectious disease outbreaks]], no such system exists (yet) to evaluate on a regular basis the effects of armed violence on peoples’ lives. With that in mind, the method developed by Taback and Coupland is a useful contribution to international efforts to enhance [[human security]], including in [[disarmament]].<ref name="blogspot2007"/>
===Use of the Taback-Coupland model=== The model has generated original and policy-relevant data in relation to subjects such as explosive force in populated areas,<ref name="slideshare1"/> and sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo<ref name="autogenerated1"/> and in Zimbabwe.<ref>Aids-Free World. (2009) ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/04-13093713 Electing to Rape: Sexual Terror in Mugabe's Zimbabwe].”</ref> A major study involving analysis of 655 attacks on health care workers and facilities was commissioned by the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC);<ref name="slideshare2"/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.d4671 |title=Delivering healthcare in situations of conflict or violence |year=2011 |last1=Nathanson |first1=V. |journal=BMJ |volume=343 |pages=d4671 |pmid=21831934}}</ref> its publication marked the launch of the ICRC’s “Health Care in Danger” project.<ref>[https://www.scribd.com/icrc/d/70209252-Red-Cross-Red-Crescent-Magazine-No-2-2011 Red Cross, Red Crescent Magazine. No. 2, 2011] Retrieved 2012-06-02.</ref><ref>[http://www.intrahealth.org/page/health-under-attack-the-need-to-safeguard-health-in-conflict Health Under Attack: The Need to Safeguard Health in Conflict] Retrieved 2012-06-02</ref> Another major ongoing project is the “Security in Numbers Database.”<ref>Christina Wille (2011). ”[http://www.slideshare.net/insecurityinsight/08-13093996 Security in Numbers Database (SiND): Monitoring Actions that Interfere with Aid Delivery]”. </ref>
==See also== *[[Armed violence reduction]] *[[Cost of conflict]] *[[Direct conflict deaths]] *[[Geneva Declaration on Armed Violence and Development]] *[[International Committee of the Red Cross]] *[[Small Arms Survey]] *[[United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research]] *[[World Health Organization]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/misc/57jq66.htm Bibliography on weapons and health] *[http://www.insecurityinsight.org Insecurity Insight's website] *[http://www.safeguardinghealth.org Safeguarding Health in Conflict]

revision.text:
An important parameter in wet scrubbing systems is the rate of liquid flow. It is common in wet [[scrubber]] terminology to express the liquid flow as a function of the gas flow rate that is being treated. This is commonly called the '''liquid-to-gas ratio''' ('''L/G ratio''') and uses the units of gallons per 1,000 actual cubic feet or litres per cubic metre (L/m<sup>3</sup>).
Expressing the amount of liquid used as a ratio enables systems of different sizes to be readily compared. For [[particulate]] removal, the liquid-to-gas ratio is a function of the mechanical design of the system; while for gas absorption this ratio gives an indication of the difficulty of removing a [[pollutant]]. Most wet scrubbers used for particulate control operate with liquid-to-gas ratios in the range of 4 to 20 gallons per 1,000 actual cubic foot (0.5 to 3 litres per actual cubic metre).
Depending on scrubber design, a minimum volume of liquid is required to "wet" the scrubber internals and create sufficient collection targets. After a certain optimum point, adding excess liquid to a particulate wet scrubber does not increase efficiency and in fact, could be counter-productive by causing excessive [[pressure drop|pressure loss]]. Liquid-to-gas ratios for gas absorption are often higher, in the range of 20 to 40 gallons per 1,000 actual cubic foot (3 to 6 litres per actual cubic metre).
L/G ratio illustrates a number of points about the choice of wet scrubbers used for gas absorption. For example, because [[flue-gas desulfurization]] systems must deal with heavy particulate loadings, open, simple designs (such as [[venturi scrubber|venturi]], [[spray tower|spray chamber]] and [[moving bed scrubber|moving bed]]) are used. Also, the liquid-to-gas ratio for the [[absorption (chemistry)|absorption]] process is higher than for particle removal and gas velocities are kept low to enhance the absorption process.
[[Solubility]] is a very important factor affecting the amount of a pollutant that can be absorbed. Solubility governs the amount of liquid required (liquid-to-gas ratio) and the necessary contact time. More soluble gases require less liquid. Also, more soluble gases will be absorbed faster.<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/apti/ US EPA Air Pollution Training Institute] developed in collaboration with North Carolina State University, College of Engineering (NCSU)</ref>
==Bibliography== * Bethea, R. M. 1978. Air Pollution Control Technology. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold. * National Asphalt Pavement Association. 1978. The Maintenance and Operation of Exhaust Systems in the Hot Mix Batch Plant. 2nd ed. Information Series 52. * Perry, J. H. (Ed.). 1973. Chemical Engineers’ Handbook. 5th ed. New York: McGraw-Hill. * Richards, J. R. 1995. Control of Particulate Emissions (APTI Course 413). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. * Richards, J. R. 1995. Control of Gaseous Emissions. (APTI Course 415). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. * Schifftner, K. C. 1979, April. Venturi scrubber operation and maintenance. Paper presented at the U.S. EPA Environmental Research Information Center. Atlanta, GA. * Semrau, K. T. 1977. Practical process design of particulate scrubbers. Chemical Engineering. 84:87-91. * U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 1982, September. Control Techniques for Particulate Emissions from Stationary Sources. Vol. 1. EPA 450/3-81-005a. * Wechselblatt, P. M. 1975. Wet scrubbers (particulates). In F. L. Cross and H. E. Hesketh (Eds.), Handbook for the Operation and Maintenance of Air Pollution Control Equipment. Westport: Technomic Publishing.
==See also== * [[Expansion ratio]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on buckthorns

revision.comment: Fix link
revision.text:
'''[[Buckthorn]]s''' (''Rhamnus'' species) are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] [[species]], including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species which feed exclusively on ''Rhamnus''
* [[Bucculatricidae]] ** Several ''[[Bucculatrix]]'' leaf-miner species: *** ''B. alaternella'' - only on Italian buckthorn (''[[Rhamnus alaternus|R. alaternus]]'') *** ''B. frangutella'' *** ''B. pseudosylvella'' - only on rock buckthorn (''[[Rhamnus saxatilis|R. saxatilis]]'') *** ''B. rhamniella'' * [[Pieridae]] ** [[Gonepteryx cleopatra|Cleopatra]] (''Gonepteryx cleopatra'') ** [[Powdered brimstone]] (''G. farinosa'') ** [[Gonepteryx rhamni|Common brimstone]] (''G. rhamni'')
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on ''Rhamnus'' and other plants
* [[Arctiidae]] **[[Common footman]] (''Eilema lurideola'') * [[Coleophoridae]] **''[[Coleophora ahenella]]'' * [[Geometridae]] **[[Common emerald]] (''Hemithea aestivaria'') **[[Engrailed (moth)|Engrailed]] (''Ectropis crepuscularia'') **[[Hebrew character]] (''Orthosia gothica'') **[[Scalloped oak]] (''Crocallis elinguaria'') **[[Winter moth]] (''Operophtera brumata'') * [[Noctuidae]] **[[Common Quaker]] (''Orthosia cerasi'') **[[Dark dagger]] (''Acronicta tridens'') **[[Dun-bar]] (''Cosmia trapezina'') * [[Saturniidae]] **[[Pavonia pavonia|Emperor moth]] (''Pavonia pavonia'')
== External links == *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Rhamnus&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Rhamnus''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Buckthorns]] [[Category:Rhamnus|Lepidoptera]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Pinus'' species}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} '''''[[Pine|Pinus]]''''', the '''pines''', is a genus of approximately 111 [[Neontology|extant]] tree and shrub species. The genus is currently split into two [[subgenus|subgenera]]: subgenus '''''Pinus''''' ('''hard pines'''), and subgenus '''''Strobus''''' ('''soft pines'''). Each of the subgenera have several [[section (botany)|sections]] within based on [[chloroplast]] DNA sequencing. Older classifications split the genus into three subgenera – subgenus ''Pinus'', subgenus ''Strobus'', and subgenus ''Ducampopinus'' ([[Pinyon pine|pinyon]], [[Bristlecone pine|bristlecone]] and lacebark pines){{cite web |title=Classification of the genus ''Pinus'' |first=Michael |last=Frankis |date=2002 |url=http://www.pinetum.org/Lovett/classification.htm |publisher=The Lovett Pinetum Charitable Foundation}} – based on cone, seed and leaf characteristics. DNA phylogeny has shown that species formerly in subgenus ''Ducampopinus'' are members of subgenus ''Strobus'', so ''Ducampopinus'' is no longer used.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005}} The species of subgenus ''Ducampopinus'' were regarded as intermediate between the other two subgenera. In the modern classification, they are placed into subgenus ''Strobus'', yet they did not fit entirely well in either so they were classified in a third subgenus. In 1888 the [[California]]n botanist [[John Gill Lemmon]] placed them in subgenus ''Pinus''. In general, this classification emphasized cone, cone scale, seed, and leaf fascicle and sheath morphology, and species in each subsection were usually recognizable by their general appearance. Pines with one fibrovascular bundle per leaf, (the former subgenera ''Strobus'' and ''Ducampopinus'') were known as ''haploxylon pines'', while pines with two fibrovascular bundles per leaf, (subgenus ''Pinus'') were called ''diploxylon pines''. Diploxylon pines tend to have harder timber and a larger amount of resin than the haploxylon pines. Several features are used to distinguish the subgenera, sections, and subsections of pines: the number of leaves (needles) per [[fascicle (botany)|fascicle]], whether the [[fascicle sheath]]s are [[deciduous]] or [[Glossary of botanical terms#persistent|persistent]], the number of [[fibrovascular bundle]]s per needle, the position of the [[resin duct]]s in the needles, the presence or shape of the seed wings, and the position of the [[Glossary of botanical terms#umbo|umbo]] and presence of a prickle on the scales of the [[seed cone]]s.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=35}} ==Subgenus ''Pinus'' {{anchor|Subgenus Pinus - yellow or hard pines}} == Subgenus ''[[Pinus subg. Pinus|Pinus]]'' includes the yellow and hard pines. Pines in this subgenus have one to five needles per fascicle and two [[fibrovascular bundle]]s per needle, and the fascicle sheaths are [[Glossary of botanical terms#persistent|persistent]], except in ''[[Pinus leiophylla|P. leiophylla]]'' and ''[[Pinus lumholtzii|P. lumholtzii]]''. Cone scales are thicker and more rigid than those of subgenus ''Strobus'', and [[pine cone|cones]] either open soon after they mature or are [[serotinous]].{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=38}} ===Section ''Pinus''=== '''Section ''[[Pinus sect. Pinus|Pinus]]''''' has two or three needles per fascicle. Cones of all species have thick scales, and all except those of ''[[Pinus pinea|P. pinea]]'' open at maturity. Species in this section are native to [[Europe]], [[Asia]], and the [[Mediterranean region|Mediterranean]], except for ''P. resinosa'' in northeastern [[North America]] and ''P. tropicalis'' in western [[Cuba]].{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=38}} * {{anchor|Subsection Incertae sedis}} '''Subsection ''[[Incertae sedis]]''''' * †''[[Pinus driftwoodensis|P. driftwoodensis]]'' – Early [[Eocene]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]]{{sfn|Stockey|1983}} ====Subsection Pinus==== [[File:Strom roka borovica velke borove 03.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus sylvestris'']] All but two species in '''Subsection ''Pinus''''' are native to Eurasia.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=38}} * ''[[Pinus densata|P. densata]]'' – Sikang pine * ''[[Pinus densiflora|P. densiflora]]'' – Japanese red pine * ''[[Pinus fragilissima|P. fragilissima]]'' * ''[[Pinus henryi|P. henryi]]''? * ''[[Pinus hwangshanensis|P. hwangshanensis]]'' – Huangshan pine * ''[[Pinus kesiya|P. kesiya]]'' – Khasi pine * ''[[Pinus latteri|P. latteri]]''? – Tenasserim pine * ''[[Pinus luchuensis|P. luchuensis]]'' – Luchu pine * ''[[Pinus massoniana|P. massoniana]]'' – Masson's pine * ''[[Pinus merkusii|P. merkusii]]'' – Sumatran pine * ''[[Pinus mugo|P. mugo]]'' – mountain pine * ''[[Pinus nigra|P. nigra]]'' – European black pine * ''[[Pinus resinosa|P. resinosa]]'' – red pine * ''[[Pinus sylvestris|P. sylvestris]]'' – Scots pine * ''[[Pinus tabuliformis|P. tabuliformis]]'' – Chinese red pine * ''[[Pinus taiwanensis|P. taiwanensis]]'' – Taiwan red pine * ''[[Pinus thunbergii|P. thunbergii]]'' – Japanese black pine * ''[[Pinus tropicalis|P. tropicalis]]'' – tropical pine * ''[[Pinus uncinata|P. uncinata]]'' * ''[[Pinus yunnanensis|P. yunnanensis]]'' – Yunnan pine ==== Subsection Pinaster==== [[File:Pinus roxburghii Dharamsala 1.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus roxburghii'']] '''Subsection ''[[Pinus subsect. Pinaster|Pinaster]]''''' contains species native to the Mediterranean, as well as ''[[Pinus roxburghii|P. roxburghii]]'' from the [[Himalayas]]. The scales of its cones lack spines.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=35}} It is named after ''P. pinaster''. * ''[[Pinus brutia|P. brutia]]'' – Turkish pine * ''[[Pinus canariensis|P. canariensis]]'' – Canary Island pine * ''[[Pinus halepensis|P. halepensis]]'' – Aleppo pine * ''[[Pinus heldreichii|P. heldreichii]]'' – Bosnian pine * ''[[Pinus pinaster|P. pinaster]]'' – maritime pine * ''[[Pinus pinea|P. pinea]]'' – stone pine [[File:Cambrils_Pi_Rodo_pinus_pinea.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus pinea'']] * ''[[Pinus roxburghii|P. roxburghii]]'' – chir pine ===Section ''Trifoliae''=== '''Section ''[[Pinus sect. Trifoliae|Trifoliae]]''''' (American hard pines), despite its name (which means "three-leaved"), has two to five needles per fascicle, or rarely eight. The cones of most species open at maturity, but a few are [[serotinous]]. All but two American hard pines belong to this section.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=38}} ====Subsection Australes==== [[File:Pinus elliottii forest3.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus elliottii'']] '''Subsection ''[[Pinus subsection Australes|Australes]]''''' is native to [[North America|North]] and [[Central America]] and islands in the [[Caribbean]].{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=35}}{{GRIN |id=28439 |name=Pinus cubensis}}{{GRIN |id=28511 |name=Pinus occidentalis}} [[File:Pinus muricata twisted tree Mendocino.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus muricata'']] The closed-cone (serotinous) species of California and Baja California, ''[[Pinus attenuata|P. attenuata]]'', ''[[Pinus muricata|P. muricata]]'', and ''[[Pinus radiata|P. radiata]]'', are sometimes placed in a separate subsection, ''Attenuatae''.{{Gymnosperm Database |family=Pinaceae |genus=Pinus}}{{Gymnosperm Database |family=Pinaceae |genus=Pinus |species=muricata}} * ''[[Pinus attenuata|P. attenuata]]'' – knobcone pine * ''[[Pinus caribaea|P. caribaea]]'' – Caribbean pine * ''[[Pinus cubensis|P. cubensis]]'' – Cuban pine * ''[[Pinus echinata|P. echinata]]'' – shortleaf pine * ''[[Pinus elliottii|P. elliottii]]'' – slash pine * ''†[[Pinus foisyi|P. foisyi]]'' – extinct * ''[[Pinus glabra|P. glabra]]'' – spruce pine * ''[[Pinus greggii|P. greggii]]'' – Gregg's pine * ''[[Pinus herrerae|P. herrerae]]'' – Herrera's pine * ''[[Pinus jaliscana|P. jaliscana]]'' – Jalisco pine * ''[[Pinus lawsonii|P. lawsonii]]'' – Lawson's pine * ''[[Pinus leiophylla|P. leiophylla]]'' – Chihuahua pine * ''[[Pinus lumholtzii|P. lumholtzii]]'' – Lumholtz's pine * †''[[Pinus matthewsii|P. matthewsii]]'' – [[Pliocene]], [[Yukon Territory]], Canada{{sfn|McKown|Stockey|Schweger|2002}} * ''[[Pinus muricata|P. muricata]]'' – bishop pine * ''[[Pinus occidentalis|P. occidentalis]]'' – Hispaniolan pine * ''[[Pinus oocarpa|P. oocarpa]]'' – egg-cone pine * ''[[Pinus palustris|P. palustris]]'' – longleaf pine * ''[[Pinus patula|P. patula]]'' – patula pine * ''[[Pinus praetermissa|P. praetermissa]]'' – McVaugh's pine * ''[[Pinus pringlei|P. pringlei]]'' – Pringle's pine * ''[[Pinus pungens|P. pungens]]'' – Table Mountain pine * ''[[Pinus radiata|P. radiata]]'' – Monterey pine * ''[[Pinus rigida|P. rigida]]'' – pitch pine * ''[[Pinus serotina|P. serotina]]'' – pond pine * ''[[Pinus taeda|P. taeda]]'' – loblolly pine * ''[[Pinus tecunumanii|P. tecunumanii]]'' – Tecun Uman pine * ''[[Pinus teocote|P. teocote]]'' – ocote pine ====Subsection Contortae==== '''Subsection ''[[Pinus subsection Contortae|Contortae]]''''' is native to North America and Mexico.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=35}} * ''[[Pinus banksiana|P. banksiana]]'' – jack pine * ''[[Pinus clausa|P. clausa]]'' – sand pine * ''[[Pinus contorta|P. contorta]]'' – lodgepole pine * ''[[Pinus virginiana|P. virginiana]]'' – Virginia pine ====Subsection Ponderosae==== [[File:Pinus jeffreyi cones BigBearLake.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus jeffreyi'']] '''Subsection ''[[Pinus subsection Ponderosae|Ponderosae]]''''' is native to [[Central America]], [[Mexico]], the western [[United States]], and southwestern [[Canada]].{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=35}}{{GRIN |id=409709 |name=Pinus hartwegii}} * ''[[Pinus arizonica|P. arizonica]]''? – Arizona pine * ''[[Pinus cooperi|P. cooperi]]'' – Cooper's pine * ''[[Pinus coulteri|P. coulteri]]'' – Coulter pine * ''[[Pinus donnell-smithii|P. donnell-smithii]]'' * ''[[Pinus devoniana|P. devoniana]]'' – Michoacan pine * ''[[Pinus douglasiana|P. douglasiana]]'' * ''[[Pinus durangensis|P. durangensis]]'' – Durango pine * ''[[Pinus engelmannii|P. engelmannii]]'' – Apache pine * ''[[Pinus hartwegii|P. hartwegii]]'' – Hartweg's pine * ''[[Pinus jeffreyi|P. jeffreyi]]'' – Jeffrey pine * †''[[Pinus johndayensis|P. johndayensis]]'' – [[Oligocene]] * ''[[Pinus maximinoi|P. maximinoi]]'' – thinleaf pine * ''[[Pinus montezumae|P. montezumae]]'' – Montezuma pine * ''[[Pinus nubicola|P. nubicola]]'' * ''[[Pinus ponderosa|P. ponderosa]]'' – ponderosa pine * ''[[Pinus pseudostrobus|P. pseudostrobus]]'' – smooth-bark Mexican pine * ''[[Pinus sabineana|P. sabiniana]]'' – gray pine * ''[[Pinus torreyana|P. torreyana]]'' – Torrey pine * ''[[Pinus washoensis|P. washoensis]]'' ==Subgenus ''Strobus'' {{anchor|Subgenus Strobus: white or soft pines}} == [[File:Pinus strobus Awenda.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus strobus'']] Subgenus ''[[Strobus]]'' includes the white and soft pines. Pines in this subgenus have one to five needles per fascicle and one [[fibrovascular bundle]] per needle, and the fascicle sheaths are [[deciduous]], except in ''[[Pinus nelsonii|P. nelsonii]]'', where they are persistent. Cone scales are thinner and more flexible than those of subgenus ''Pinus'', except in some species like ''[[Pinus maximartinezii|P. maximartinezii]]'', and [[pine cone|cones]] usually open soon after they mature.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=38}} ===Section ''Parrya''=== '''Section ''[[Pinus sect. Parrya|Parrya]]''''' has one to five needles per fascicle. The seeds either have [[Glossary of botanical terms#articulate|articulate]] (jointed) wings or no wings at all. In all species except for ''P. nelsonii'', the fascicle sheaths curl back to form a [[rosette (botany)|rosette]] before falling away. The cones have thick scales and release the seeds at maturity. This section is native to the southwestern United States and Mexico.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=38}} ====Subsection Balfourianae==== '''[[Pinus subsect. Balfourianae|Subsection ''Balfourianae]]''' (bristlecone pines) is native to southwest [[United States]]. * ''[[Pinus aristata|P. aristata]]'' – Rocky Mountains bristlecone pine * ''[[Pinus balfouriana|P. balfouriana]]'' – foxtail pine * ''[[Pinus longaeva|P. longaeva]]'' – Great Basin bristlecone pine ====Subsection Cembroides==== [[File:Pinus cembroides Chisos 1.jpg|thumb|right|''Pinus cembroides'']] '''[[Pinyon pine|Subsection ''Cembroides]]''' (pinyons or piñons) is native to [[Mexico]] and the southwestern [[United States]]. * ''[[Pinus cembroides|P. cembroides]]'' – Mexican pinyon * ''[[Pinus culminicola|P. culminicola]]'' – Potosi pinyon * ''[[Pinus discolor|P. discolor]]'' – border pinyon * ''[[Pinus edulis|P. edulis]]'' – Colorado pinyon * ''[[Pinus johannis|P. johannis]]'' – Johann's pinyon * ''[[Pinus maximartinezii|P. maximartinezii]]'' – big-cone pinyon * ''[[Pinus monophylla|P. monophylla]]'' – single-leaf pinyon * ''[[Pinus orizabensis|P. orizabensis]]'' – Orizaba pinyon * ''[[Pinus pinceana|P. pinceana]]'' – weeping pinyon * ''[[Pinus quadrifolia|P. quadrifolia]]'' – Parry pinyon * ''[[Pinus remota|P. remota]]'' – Texas pinyon or papershell pinyon * ''[[Pinus rzedowskii|P. rzedowskii]]'' – Rzedowski's pinyon ====Subsection Nelsonianae==== '''Subsection ''Nelsonianae''''' is native to northeastern Mexico. It consists of the single species with persistent fascicle sheaths. * ''[[Pinus nelsonii|P. nelsonii]]'' – Nelson's pinyon ===Section ''Quinquefoliae''=== '''Section ''Quinquefoliae''''' (white pines), as its name (which means "five-leaved") suggests, has five needles per fascicle except for ''[[Pinus krempfii|P. krempfii]]'', which has two, and ''[[Pinus gerardiana|P. gerardiana]]'' and ''[[Pinus bungeana|P. bungeana]]'', which have three. All species have cones with thin or thick scales that open at maturity or do not open at all; none are serotinous. Species in this section are found in Eurasia and North America, and one species, ''[[Pinus chiapensis|P. chiapensis]]'' reaches Guatemala.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|pp=38–39}}{{GRIN |id=457536 |name=Pinus chiapensis}} ====Subsection Gerardianae==== '''Subsection ''[[Pinus subsection Gerardianae|Gerardianae]]''''' is native to East Asia. It has three or five needles per fascicle. * ''[[Pinus bungeana|P. bungeana]]'' – lacebark pine * ''[[Pinus gerardiana|P. gerardiana]]'' – chilgoza pine * ''[[Pinus squamata|P. squamata]]'' – Qiaojia pine ====Subsection Krempfianae==== '''Subsection ''Krempfianae''''' is native to Vietnam. It has two needles per fascicle, and they are atypically flattened. The cone scales are thick and have no prickles. * ''[[Pinus krempfii|P. krempfii]]'' – [[Krempf's Pine]] ====Subsection Strobus==== [[File:Pinus cembra cones in Gröden.JPG|thumb|right|''Pinus cembra'']] '''Subsection ''[[Pinus subsect. Strobus|Strobus]]''''' has five needles per fascicle and thin cone scales with no prickles. It is native to North and Central America, Europe, and Asia.{{sfn|Gernandt|López|García|Liston|2005|p=35}} * ''[[Pinus albicaulis|P. albicaulis]]'' – whitebark pine * ''[[Pinus amamiana|P. amamiana]]'' – Yakushima white pine * ''[[Pinus armandii|P. armandii]]'' – Chinese white pine * ''[[Pinus ayacahuite|P. ayacahuite]]'' – Mexican white pine * ''[[Pinus bhutanica|P. bhutanica]]'' – Bhutan white pine * ''[[Pinus cembra|P. cembra]]'' – Swiss pine * ''[[Pinus chiapensis|P. chiapensis]]'' – Chiapas pine * ''[[Pinus dabeshanensis|P. dabeshanensis]]'' – Dabieshan pine * ''[[Pinus dalatensis|P. dalatensis]]'' – Vietnamese white pine * ''[[Pinus fenzeliana|P. fenzeliana]]'' – Hainan white pine * ''[[Pinus flexilis|P. flexilis]]'' – limber pine * ''[[Pinus koraiensis|P. koraiensis]]'' – Korean pine * ''[[Pinus lambertiana|P. lambertiana]]'' – sugar pine * ''[[Pinus monticola|P. monticola]]'' – western white pine * ''[[Pinus morrisonicola|P. morrisonicola]]'' – Taiwan white pine * ''[[Pinus parviflora|P. parviflora]]'' – Japanese white pine ** ''[[Pinus hakkodensis|P. hakkodensis]]'' – Hakkoda pine * ''[[Pinus peuce|P. peuce]]'' – Macedonian pine * ''[[Pinus pumila|P. pumila]]'' – Siberian dwarf pine * ''[[Pinus sibirica|P. sibirica]]'' – Siberian pine * ''[[Pinus strobus|P. strobus]]'' – eastern white pine * ''[[Pinus strobiformis|P. strobiformis]]'' – Southwestern white pine (also Chihuahuan) * ''[[Pinus wallichiana|P. wallichiana]]'' – blue pine * ''[[Pinus wangii|P. wangii]]'' – Guangdong white pine ==''Incertae sedis''== Species which are not placed in a subgenus at this time. * †''P. peregrinus'' – ''[[Pinus peregrinus]]'' – Middle [[Eocene]], [[Golden Valley Formation]], [[North Dakota]], USA ==References== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite journal |last1=Gernandt |first1=D. S. |last2=López |first2=G. G. |last3=García |first3=S. O. |last4=Liston |first4=A. |year=2005 |title= Phylogeny and classification of ''Pinus'' |journal=Taxon |volume=54 |issue= 1 |pages=29–42 |doi= 10.2307/25065300 |jstor = 25065300 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |last1=McKown |first1=A.D. |last2=Stockey |first2=R.A. |last3=Schweger |first3=C.E. |year=2002 |title=A New Species of ''Pinus'' Subgenus ''Pinus'' Subsection ''Contortae'' From Pliocene Sediments of Ch'Ijee's Bluff, Yukon Territory, Canada |journal=International Journal of Plant Sciences |volume=163 |issue=4 |pages=687–697 |url=http://www.mckown.ca/PDF/McKownetal2002.pdf |archive-url=http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20080221182400/http://www.mckown.ca/PDF/McKownetal2002.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-02-21 |doi=10.1086/340425 |ref=harv}} * {{Cite journal|last1=Stockey |first1=R.S. |year=1983 |title=''Pinus driftwoodensis'' sp.n. from the early Tertiary of British Columbia |journal= Botanical Gazette |volume=144 |issue=1 |pages=148–156 |jstor=2474678 |doi=10.1086/337355 |ref=harv}} ==External links== * [http://tolweb.org/Pinus Tree of Life Web] favors classification of ''Ducampopinus'' species in ''Strobus''. * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/Browser/wwwtax.cgi?id=3337 NCBI Taxonomy server] files ''Ducampopinus'' species above as ''Strobus''. {{Commons category|position=left|Pinus|
Pinus}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pinus Classification}} [[Category:Pinus|*]] [[Category:Lists of plant species|Pinus]] [[Category:Lists of plants|Pinus]] [[Category:Lists of trees|Pinus]]

revision.text:
{{overly detailed|date=February 2017|reason=this list includes non-notable events – I've added inclusion criteria and an "overly detailed" tag – we don't need to be listing low intensity events. If a reader wants an earthquake catalog, find an earthquake catalog. That's not what we're doing here. We're an encyclopedia and we talk about notable events}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}} This is a list of significant earthquakes recorded within [[Australia]] and its territories. The currency used is the [[Australian dollar]] (A$) unless noted otherwise. ==List of earthquakes== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! State !! Location !! Date !! M !! !! [[Mercalli intensity scale|MMI]] !! Deaths !! Injuries !! Total damage / notes !! |- | | Offshore [[Cape Schanck, Victoria|Cape Schanck]] | 1855-09-17 | 5.5 | | | | | Minor damage in Melbourne and surroundings.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] | 1868-06-18 | 5.3 | | | | | Damage in [[Hunter Street (Newcastle)|Hunter Street]] and the Newcastle suburbs of [[The Hill, New South Wales|The Hill]] and [[Wallsend, New South Wales|Wallsend]] (then known as Pitt Town). | {{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18733237?searchTerm=Newcastle%20earthquake|work=Trove|publisher=[[The Maitland Mercury]]|date=23 June 1868|accessdate=16 August 2010|title=NEWCASTLE}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | Eastern Highlands | 1869-08-30 | 5.4 | | | | | Light building damage and smashed windows reported around the Mt Hotham region including in Benalla and Omeo. Felt widely across eastern Victoria and southern New South Wales, including Melbourne and Albury. | |- | [[South Australia]] | [[Dorset Vale, South Australia|Dorset Vale]] | 1883-07-07 | 4.7 | | IV | | 1 | Felt strongly throughout southern South Australia including within Adelaide where one man was injured after jumping out through a window due to fright. | |- | [[Queensland]] | [[Gayndah, Queensland|Gayndah]] | 1883-08-28 | 5.9 | | | | | Caused major damage in the Gayndah region. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/c05b764ac1295af0ca256d330005820b?OpenDocument|title=Gayndah, Qld: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916060827/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/c05b764ac1295af0ca256d330005820b?OpenDocument|archivedate=16 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Tasmania]] | [[Flinders Island]] | 1884-07-13 | 6.4 | | VI | | | Felt across Tasmania and in eastern Victoria (MMIII-IV). Extensive minor damage across eastern Tasmania including fallen plaster, cracked ceilings and walls, damaged chimneys in Launceston (MMV) and items knocked from shelves. Part of the 1883-1892 West Tasman Sea earthquake swarm. | |- | [[Tasmania]] | [[Flinders Island]] | 1884-09-19 | 6.4 | | VI | | | Felt across Tasmania and in eastern Victoria. Minor damage in northwest Tasmania. Part of the 1883-1892 West Tasman Sea earthquake swarm. | |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Geraldton, Western Australia|Geraldton]] | 1885-01-05 | 6.5 | | V | | 1 | Minor damage to buildings. Epicentre estimated to be off Geraldton coast. | |- | [[Tasmania]] | [[Flinders Island]] | 1885-05-13 | 6.8 | | VI | | | Felt across Tasmania and large parts of Victoria, including in Melbourne and Geelong (MMIII), as well as in southeastern New South Wales (MMMIV-V). Extensive minor damage across eastern Tasmania including fallen plaster, cracked ceilings and walls, damaged chimneys, items knocked from shelves, and damage to church spires. Part of the 1883-1892 West Tasman Sea earthquake swarm. | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Cape Liptrap]] | 1885-07-02 | 5.7 | | | | | Tied with the 1922 and 1965 events as Victoria's largest earthquake. Felt throughout Victoria, including Melbourne and Geelong. Minor damage around epicentre. | |- | [[New South Wales]]/[[Australian Capital Territory|ACT]] | [[Yass, New South Wales|Yass]] | 1886-11-15 | 5.5 | | | | | Damage caused in Yass, felt strongly in [[Queanbeyan, New South Wales|Queanbeyan]]. | {{cite web|url=https://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA11006.pdf|title=Earthquakes in the Canberra Region|format=PDF|author=Marion Leiba|publisher=[[Geoscience Australia]]|date=December 2007|accessdate=5 April 2009|page=22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301231005/http://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA11006.pdf|archivedate=1 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Tasmania]] | [[Flinders Island]] | 1892-01-27 | 6.9 | | VIII | | | Felt across Tasmania (MMIV-VI), Victoria (MMIII-V), and southeastern New South Wales (MMV). Extensive minor damage across eastern Tasmania including fallen plaster, cracked ceilings and walls, damaged chimneys, and collapsed verandahs. Part of the 1883-1892 West Tasman Sea earthquake swarm. | |- | [[South Australia]] | [[Beachport, South Australia|Beachport]] - [[Robe, South Australia|Robe]] | 1897-05-10 | 6.5 | UK | IX | | 50 | | {{harvnb|NGDC}}{{citation|title=Australia's worst earthquakes|url=http://www.australiangeographic.com.au/journal/australias-worst-earthquakes-top-10-most-devastating.htm|first=Tiffany|last=Hoy|date=July 10, 2012|publisher=[[Australian Geographic]]}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Portarlington, Victoria|Portarlington]] | 1899-11-23 | 4.7 | | V | | | Minor damage reported around Portalington and nearby towns including large cracks, smashed windows, and items thrown from shelves. Felt widely across Melbourne, Geelong, and western Gippsland. | |- | [[South Australia (Australia)|South Australia]] | [[Warooka, South Australia|Warooka]] | 1902-09-19 | 6.0 | | VIII | 2 | 1 | Widespread damage to the town's many stone buildings. Minor damage and panic in Adelaide. First earthquake in Australia to have caused fatalities. | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Warrnambool, Victoria|Warrnambool]] | 1903-07-14 | 5.3 | | VII | | | Regarded as Victoria's most damaging earthquake, extensive minor damage occurred throughout Warrnambool and a few nearby towns. Minor damage also occurred by a magnitude 5.0 foreshock in April. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] | 1906-05-16 | UK | | | | | Damage in the suburb of [[The Hill, New South Wales|The Hill]]. Ruptured water mains. Caused some cliff erosion | {{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article108908778?searchTerm=newcastle%20earthquake&searchLimits=|work=Trove|publisher=[[The Border Morning Mail and Riverina Times]]|date=17 May 1906|accessdate=11 Mar 2015|title="EARTHQUAKE" AT NEWCASTLE}}{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25639669?searchTerm=newcastle%20earthquake&searchLimits=|work=Trove|publisher=[[ The West Australian]]|date=16 May 1906|accessdate=11 Mar 2015|title=A "CREEP" AT NEWCASTLE}} |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Taree, New South Wales|Taree]] - [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] | 1916-06-11 | UK | | | | | Damage to the Seal Rocks lighthouse. Caused alarm along the Mid-North Coast. | {{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article166793322?searchTerm=earthquake%20newcastle&searchLimits=l-decade=191|work=Trove|publisher=[[The Wingham Chronicle and Manning River Observer]]|date=14 June 1916|accessdate=11 March 2015|title=Shock of Earthquake}} |- | [[Queensland]] | [[Bundaberg, Queensland|Bundaberg]] - [[Rockhampton, Queensland|Rockhampton]] | 1918-06-07 | 6.0 | | VI | | | Offshore. Caused "serious damage" to Rockhampton, Bundaberg and [[Gladstone, Queensland|Gladstone]]. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/3cac41abb1233f37ca256d3300057cf8?OpenDocument|title=Bundaberg - Rockhampton, Qld: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916060531/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/3cac41abb1233f37ca256d3300057cf8?OpenDocument|archivedate=16 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | Offshore [[Ocean Grove, Victoria|Ocean Grove]] | 1922-04-10 | 5.7 | | V | | |Chimney collapse in Glen Iris. Objects thrown from shelves in Cranbourne, East Malvern, Pakenham and Portalington. Felt as far north as Ivanhoe, as far west as Warnambool and as far south as Burnie, Tasmania. A magnitude 4.9 earthquake struck a few kilometres east of this earthquake back on the morning of 1 March 1922, which was felt throughout Melbourne, knocking picture frames off a wall in Cowes. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] | 1925-12-18 | 5.3 | | | | | Damage and panic in Hunter Street (particularly at the Theatre Royal). | {{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/328d59130853779bca256d33000580f1?OpenDocument|title=Boolaroo (Hunter region) NSW: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916060324/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/328d59130853779bca256d33000580f1?OpenDocument|archivedate=16 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Tasmania]] | North East [[Tasmania]] | 1929-12-29 | 5.6 | | | | | Significant damage in [[Launceston, Tasmania]]; felt across Western Tasmania from [[Burnie, Tasmania|Burnie]] to [[Hobart, Tasmania|Hobart]]. | {{Cite web |url=http://www.aees.org.au/Articles/McCue_TAS_EQs.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=18 November 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612002321/http://www.aees.org.au/Articles/McCue_TAS_EQs.pdf |archive-date=12 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51638653? |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Benalla, Victoria|Benalla]] | 1931-04-17 | 4.5 | | VI | | |Largest event in a series of earthquakes that occurred near Benalla during the 1930s. Damage included smashed windows, large cracks, collapsed chimneys, and items thrown from shelves. | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Mornington Peninsula]] | 1932-09-03 | 5.1 | | VI | | 3 |Minor damage caused throughout the Mornington Peninsula. Recent analysis has relocated the epicentre to in-between the towns of Moorooduc, Somerville, and Tyabb. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Gunning, New South Wales|Gunning]] | 1934-11-15 | 5.6 | | | | | Damaged a majority of the buildings in [[Gunning, New South Wales|Gunning]]. Felt strongly in [[Canberra]]. | |- | [[Queensland]] | [[Gayndah, Queensland|Gayndah]] | 1935-04-12 | 5.4 | | VI | 1 | | Caused considerable damage to the town of [[Gayndah, Queensland|Gayndah]]. One fatality.20 August 2011. [http://www.seismicity.see.uwa.edu.au/welcome/seismicity_in_australia#INTRO Seismicity in Australia]. University of Western Australia. Retrieved 20 June 2012. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/e3693cfe4099c7f6ca256d3300057cff?OpenDocument|title=Gayndah, Qld: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916060240/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/e3693cfe4099c7f6ca256d3300057cff?OpenDocument|archivedate=16 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Monbulk, Victoria|Monbulk]] | 1937-06-18 | 3.6 | | V | | 1 |Although a minor earthquake, recent newspaper analysis discovered that this earthquake may have triggered a mining related injury in Moorooduc where a loosened rock fell and struck a young man, resulting in a broken arm. | |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Meeberrie]] | 1941-04-29 | 6.3 | | VIII | | | Severe shaking, burst water tanks and cracked ground at Meeberrie homestead. Minor damage reported in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], {{Convert|500|km|mi|0}} away. | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] / [[Tasmania]] | [[Bass Strait]] | 1946-09-15 | 6.2 | | | | 1 | Minor damage reported in Tasmania from [[Burnie, Tasmania|Burnie]] to [[Huonville, Tasmania|Huonville]], and in [[Gippsland]], Victoria. Offshore earthquake | {{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article26357640?|title=Bass Strait Earthquake}}{{cite web|url=http://www.seis.com.au/OldEQ/EQ_info/1892_01.html |title=Unknown}}{{dead link|date=June 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/3b981b46713fd9faca256d3300057d02?OpenDocument|title=Launceston, Tas: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916060452/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/3b981b46713fd9faca256d3300057d02?OpenDocument|archivedate=16 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Dalton, New South Wales|Dalton]] and [[Gunning, New South Wales|Gunning]] | 1949-03-10 | 5.5 | | | | | Significant damage in Dalton and Gunning; minor cracks in some buildings in [[Canberra]]. Felt from [[Sydney]] in the north to [[Narooma, New South Wales|Narooma]] and [[Cooma, New South Wales|Cooma]] in the south. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/68733dc8fbc43305ca256d3300057d04?OpenDocument|title=Dalton and Gunning, NSW: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916060906/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/68733dc8fbc43305ca256d3300057d04?OpenDocument|archivedate=16 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[South Australia]] | [[Adelaide]] | [[1954 Adelaide earthquake|1954-03-01]] | 5.5 | |VIII | | 16 | Damage totaling $90 million. Widespread minor damage. Considerable damage to many buildings. | {{cite web|url=http://www.samuseum.sa.gov.au/Journals/TRSSA/TRSSA_V079/TRSSA_V079_p177p185.pdf |title=The Adelaide Earthquake of 1st March 1954 |format=PDF |author=C. Kerr-Grant |publisher=[[South Australian Museum]] |date=10 November 1955 |accessdate=4 April 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }};
{{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/affba43fc3009495ca256d3300057c45?OpenDocument |title=Adelaide, SA: Earthquake |work=EMA Disasters Database |publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]] |date=13 September 2006 |accessdate=5 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817182000/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/affba43fc3009495ca256d3300057c45?OpenDocument |archivedate=17 August 2008 |df= }} |- | [[Western Australia]] | Gabalong | 1955-08-30 | 5.8 | | V | | | Felt in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]]. Epicentre near Gabalong, about 30 km east of [[Moora, Western Australia|Moora]] and 200 km NNE of Perth | [http://www.ga.gov.au/earthquakes/getQuakeDetails.do?quakeId=38147&orid=619601&sta= Gabalong WA: Earthquake details]. Geoscience Australia. Retrieved 20 June 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.seismicity.see.uwa.edu.au/welcome/seismicity_of_western_australia/wa_historical |title=Seismicity of Western Australia - Large earthquakes of Western Australia |publisher=Seismicity.see.uwa.edu.au |date= |accessdate=20 June 2012}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | Cape Otway | 1960-12-25 | 5.3 | | V | | | No major damage reported. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Robertson, New South Wales|Robertson]] and [[Bowral, New South Wales|Bowral]] | [[1961 New South Wales earthquake|1961-05-21]] | 5.5 | ML | VII | | | $3.4 million | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | Mt Hotham | 1966-05-04 | 5.5 | | V | | | Broken Windows at Mt Hotham Ski Village. Felt across North-eastern Victoria, Gippsland and South-eastern New South Wales. Not felt in Melbourne. | |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Meckering, Western Australia|Meckering]] | [[1968 Meckering earthquake|1968-10-14]] | 6.5 | Mw | IX | | 33 | $2.2 million | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Boolarra, Victoria]] | 1969-06-20 | 5.3 | | VI | | | 5.0 aftershock two days later. Cracked walls and stacked chimneys in and around epicentral area. Felt in central and eastern [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] including [[Geelong]], Benalla and Orbost and on Flinders Island. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ga.gov.au/earthquakes/getQuakeDetails.do?quakeId=135785 |title=Earthquakes @ GA — Earthquake Details |publisher=Ga.gov.au |date= |accessdate=20 June 2012}} |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Lake Mackay]] | 1970-03-24 | 6.0 | | | | | Little damage due to the remoteness of the area. Part of a sequence of c. 25 quakes of magnitude 5.0 or greater in the Canning Basin area of northern Western Australia between 1970 and 1982. | {{cite web|url=http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1970s_Canning.html |title=Unknown |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719191203/http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1970s_Canning.html |archivedate=19 July 2008 }} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Western Port]] | 1971-07-07 | 5.0 | | VI | | | Minor damage in Cowes, Flinders and Shoreham. Felt throughout Melbourne, Western Port Bay and Gippsland. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Picton, New South Wales|Picton]] | 1973-03-10 | 5.5 | | VI | | | Damage totalling $2.8 million. Minor damage in Picton, [[Bowral, New South Wales|Bowral]] and [[Wollongong, New South Wales|Wollongong]] | {{cite web|url=http://www.aees.org.au/gallery/1973-picton/|title=The big shake...|publisher=[[Sun-Herald]]|date=11 March 1973}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Balliang, Victoria|Balliang]] | 1977-12-02 | 4.7 | | V | | 1 | Felt strongly in [[Geelong, Victoria|Geelong]] and across the suburbs of [[Melbourne, Victoria|Melbourne]], caused minor damage in the [[Anakie, Victoria|Anakie]] area. | {{cite web|url=http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1977_12.html |title=Unknown |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913022546/http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1977_12.html |archivedate=13 September 2009 }} |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Cadoux, Western Australia|Cadoux]] | 1979-06-02 | 6.1 | | IX | | 5 | 25 buildings in Cadoux were damaged. Damage cost $3.8 million. Perth, {{Convert|180|km|mi|0}} away experienced some swaying of tall buildings but no damage was reported. This was one of the largest onshore earthquakes recorded in Australia. | {{cite web|url=http://www.seismicity.see.uwa.edu.au/welcome/seismicity_of_western_australia/wa_historical/cadoux|title=The Cadoux Earthquake, 2 June 1979|work=Seismicity of Western Australia|publisher=[[University of Western Australia]]|date=28 March 2004|accessdate=4 April 2009}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | Wonnangatta, Victoria | 1982-11-21 | 5.4 | | V | | | The epicentre was in the remote Wonnangatta Valley, along the Wonnangatta Fault; it was mostly felt widely in Eastern [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and South Eastern [[New South Wales]] and throughout [[Melbourne]] and its South Eastern suburbs but not in [[Geelong]]. Minor damage was reported in nearby towns. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ga.gov.au/earthquakes/getQuakeDetails.do?quakeId=2464095 |title=Earthquakes @ GA — Earthquake Details |publisher=Ga.gov.au |date= |accessdate=20 June 2012}} |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Wyalong, New South Wales|Wyalong]] | 1982-11-26 | 4.6 | | VI | | | The largest event in a series of earthquakes that occurred near Wyalong during 1982. Extensive minor damage reported in Wyalong, West Wyalong, and surrounding towns. In Wyalong damage included cracking of external and internal walls, items thrown from shelves, and a partly collapsed shop awning. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Oolong, New South Wales|Oolong]] | 1984-08-09 | 4.3 | | V | | | Minor damage in and around the town of Oolong, including in the town of Dalton where the spire of St Matthews Anglican Church was permanently knocked side ways. Produced the highest Peak Ground Acceleration reading in Australian history. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Lithgow, New South Wales|Lithgow]] | 1985-02-13 | 4.3 | | V-VII | | | Minor damage in and around the town of Lithgow including demolished chimneys, smashed windows, and cracked masonry walls. Power outages were also reported. The total damage came to $65,000. | |- | [[Northern Territory]] | Marryat Creek | 1986-10-30 | 5.9 | | | | | Damage was minor, cracked walls observed in [[DeRose Hill]] and [[Victory Downs]] stations. Felt in [[Alice Springs, Northern Territory|Alice Springs]] {{Convert|300|km|mi|0}} to the north, and [[Coober Pedy, South Australia|Coober Pedy]] {{Convert|350|km|mi|0}} to the south. | {{cite web|url=http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1986_03.html |title=Unknown |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913002100/http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1986_03.html |archivedate=13 September 2009 }} |- | [[Northern Territory]] | [[Tennant Creek, Northern Territory|Tennant Creek]] | 1988-01-22 | 6.2, 6.3, 6.6 | | VII | | | Two buildings and 3 other structures damaged, damage caused to natural gas pipeline. Total damage $2.5 million. Three earthquakes of between 6.3 and 6.7 on the Richter scale. Remarkably caused little damage, despite the intensity of the quake. Felt in high-rise buildings as far away as [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] and [[Adelaide, South Australia|Adelaide]] | {{cite journal|last=Bowman|first=J.R.|title=The 1988 Tennant Creek, northern territory, earthquakes: A synthesis|journal=Australian Journal of Earth Sciences|date=November 1992|volume=39|issue=5|pages=651–669|doi=10.1080/08120099208728056|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08120099208728056#.UbXafPmL9qA|accessdate=10 June 2013}}http://www.emknowledge.gov.au/resource/?id=465 |- | [[Northern Territory]] | [[Uluru]] | 1989-05-28 | 5.7 | | VII | | | Minor damage was reported at [[Yulara]] resort | {{cite web|url=http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1989_05.html |title=Unknown |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719191553/http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/EQ_info/1989_05.html |archivedate=19 July 2008 }} |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Newcastle, New South Wales]] | [[1989 Newcastle earthquake|1989-12-28]] | 5.6 | ML | VIII | 13 | 160 | $4 billion in damage | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Ellalong, New South Wales|Ellalong]] | 1994-08-06 | 5.4 | | | | 5 | 1,000 homes and 50 other buildings damaged. Total damage $36 million. | {{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/c85916e930b93d50ca256d050020cb1f/bb6358c39d833121ca256d3300057c0a?OpenDocument|title=Ellalong - Cessnock (Hunter Valley), NSW: Earthquake|work=EMA Disasters Database|publisher=[[Emergency Management Australia]]|date=13 September 2006|accessdate=4 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010050709/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/c85916e930b93d50ca256d050020cb1f/bb6358c39d833121ca256d3300057c0a?OpenDocument|archivedate=10 October 2007|df=dmy-all}} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Mount Baw Baw]] | 1996-09-25 | 5.0 | | VI | | | Despite the minor damage reported around the quake's epicentre, this event is noteworthy as it was the largest earthquake in a swarm triggered by the creation of the Thomson Dam, dating back to the late 1970s. | {{cite web |url=http://www.users.bigpond.net.au/lccchistory/page38.html |title=Baw Baw Highlights |accessdate=4 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070528140056/http://www.users.bigpond.net.au/lccchistory/page38.html |archivedate=28 May 2007 |df=dmy-all }};
{{cite web |url=http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/Isoseismal/19960925MtBawBaw.html |title=1996-09-25, Thomson Reservoir, Intensity Map |publisher=seismology research centre |accessdate=4 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913022818/http://www.seis.com.au/EQ/Isoseismal/19960925MtBawBaw.html |archivedate=13 September 2009 |df= }} |- | [[South Australia]] | [[Burra, South Australia|Burra]] | 1997-03-05 | 5.0 | | | | | No major damage. Felt over a wide area. | |- | [[Western Australia]] | Collier Bay | 1997-08-10 | 6.3 | [[Moment magnitude scale|Mw]] | | | | No major damage. Felt from [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]] to [[Halls Creek, Western Australia|Halls Creek]] and [[Kununurra, Western Australia|Kununurra]]. Strongest earthquake recorded in Australia since the 1988 Tennant Creek earthquake. | |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Appin, New South Wales]], southwest of [[Sydney]] | 1999-03-17 | 4.8 | | V | | | {{Convert|65|km|mi|0}} southwest of [[Sydney, New South Wales]]. Depth only 3.2 km. Felt in Sydney and caused 1000 homes to lose power. | {{cite web |url=http://www.aees.org.au/Newsletters/AEES_2000_2.pdf |title=AEES Newsletter |publisher=aees.org.au |date=February 2000 |accessdate=20 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323075212/http://www.aees.org.au/Newsletters/AEES_2000_2.pdf |archivedate=23 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Boolarra, Victoria]] | 2000-08-29 | 5.0 | | V | | | Caused minor damage. Felt strongly throughout Gippsland and Melbourne. | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Swan Hill, Victoria]] | 2001-10-27 | 4.8 | | V | | | Felt in Swan Hill near VIC–NSW border, Minor damage including fallen chimneys and fallen shelve items. Power disruptions. | |- | [[Tasmania (Australia)|Tasmania]] | [[Beaconsfield, Tasmania]] | 2006-04-25 | 2.2 | | | 1 | 2 | This micro earthquake triggered the Beaconsfiled Mine Collapse. | |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Kalgoorlie, Western Australia|Kalgoorlie]] | 2010-04-20 | 5.2 | Mw | V | | 2 | Extensive damage to buildings throughout Kalgoorlie- Boulder. | |- | [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | [[Gippsland]] | [[2012 Gippsland earthquake|2012-06-19]] | 5.4 | ML | VI | | 1 | Minor extensive damage reported around the Gippsland area, including smashed windows, items thrown from shelves, destroyed chimneys, and ceiling tile collapses. An indirect minor injury reported from a man who fell from a ladder in Melbourne's suburbs. Damage bill in the millions. Largest aftershock was a magnitude 4.4 just over a month later, and was too felt across Gippsland and Melbourne. | |- | [[Queensland]] | [[Coral Sea]] | 2015-07-30 | 5.5 | Mw | V | | | Slight building damage | {{cite web|title=M 5.5 - 128km ENE of Rainbow Beach, Australia|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us10002w8v#executive|author=USGS|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]}} |- | [[New South Wales]] | [[Orange, NSW]] | 2017-04-13 | 4.3 | Mw | IV | | 3 | Slight damage to [[Cadia-Ridgeway Mine]] and was felt in Orange, [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]], [[Blayney, New South Wales|Blayney]], Millthorpe, Molong and surrounds. Caused damage to houses and farms 7 km around. | {{cite web|title=NSW earthquake: Gold mine evacuated, residents in Orange woken up by shaking|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-04-14/earthquake-shocks-orange-residents-as-mine-evacuated/8444956|author=Kathleen Calderwood|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]}} |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Lake Muir]] | 2018-9-16 | 5.7 | Mw | | | | No damage, felt in [[South West (Western Australia)|South West]], [[Great Southern (Western Australia)|Great Southern]], [[Peel (Western Australia)|Peel]] and [[Wheatbelt (Western Australia)|Wheatbelt]] regions.{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-16/earth-tremor-rocks-southern-wa-town-of-walpole/10253364|title=Magnitude-5.7 earthquake rocks southern WA|date=17 September 2018|accessdate=9 November 2018|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}} |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Lake Muir]] | 2018-10-13 | 4.7 | Mw | | | |{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-10-13/small-earthquake-near-lake-muir/10373358|title=Magnitude-4.7 earthquake rocks area surrounding Lake Muir in WA's Great Southern|date=13 October 2018|accessdate=9 November 2018|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}} |- | [[Western Australia]] | [[Lake Muir]] | 2018-11-9 | 5.4 | Mw | | | |{{cite web|url=https://www.news.com.au/national/western-australia/earthquake-at-lake-muir-shakes-perth-and-was-south-west/news-story/3e12a99c3ead643f1d0d5de53507936e|title=Earthquake at Lake Muir shakes Perth and WA’s South West|author=Ben Anserson|date=9 November 2018|accessdate=9 November 2018|publisher=[[News Corporation]]}} |- class="sortbottom" | colspan="10" style="text-align: center;" |The inclusion criteria for adding events are based on [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Earthquakes|WikiProject Earthquakes]]' [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Earthquakes/notability guidelines|notability guideline]] that was developed for stand alone articles. The principles described are also applicable to lists. In summary, only damaging, injurious, or deadly events should be recorded. Mw = [[moment magnitude scale]] | Ms = [[surface wave magnitude]] | UK = Unknown |} ==Other earthquakes== *[[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]], 16 August 1929, magnitude 6.6, offshore earthquake to the north-west of Broome, Western Australia. *[[Simpson Desert]], 21 December 1937, magnitude 6.0, in a remote location of the Simpson Desert in the Northern Territory, south-east of Alice Springs. *[[Simpson Desert]], 27 June 1941, magnitude 6.5, in a remote location of the Simpson Desert in the Northern Territory, south-east of Alice Springs. ==See also== {{Portal|Australia|Geology}} *[[Earthquakes in Western Australia]] *[[Geology of Australia]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} '''Sources''' {{refbegin}} * {{citation|title=Significant Earthquake Database|url=https://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/form?t=101650&s=1&d=1|author=NGDC|publisher=[[National Geophysical Data Center]], [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|doi=10.7289/V5TD9V7K}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline|Earthquakes in Australia}} * [http://www.seismicity.see.uwa.edu.au/welcome/seismicity_in_australia Seismicity in Australia] * [https://d28rz98at9flks.cloudfront.net/74811/Rec2012_071.pdf The 2012 Australian Earthquake Hazard Map] – [[Geoscience Australia]] {{Earthquakes in Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Earthquakes In Australia}} [[Category:Earthquakes in Australia|*]] [[Category:Australia geology-related lists|earthquakes]] [[Category:Lists of earthquakes by country|Australia]] [[Category:Lists of disasters in Australia]]
